div.p: 1. VII. At Noon I called according to his appointment at Lord Sidmouth’s Office, and was informed that he had gone out of town— I then enquired for Mr Beckett, and saw him— He apologized to me for Lord Sidmouth, and said that he had no doubt that he could easily arrange with me, the subject upon which I had spoken to his Lordship— I mentioned the difficulty which within these few days in obtaining from the alien Office, Passports to go to France— Until the Commencement of hostilities, they had always obtained those Passports at the Alien-Office, upon producing there passports given by me— Within the last week, those who have applied, were told that they must have something more from me than a Passport. A Letter, or request that they might be permitted to go to France. I said that whatever of this Nature was thought necessary by this Government I would readily give; it being understood that all I should pledge myself to by it is that the person applying is an American Citizen; and that he wishes to go to France. I should certainly not give it to any person of whom I should know that he was going with purposes hostile to this Country, but I must of course give it to many persons total strangers to me, and of whose purposes I shall have no knowledge— As American Citizens all have an equal right to ask all the facilities that I can give them for travelling; and as belonging to a neutral Country, all have an equal right to go to France, as their affairs or inclinations may lead them— It happened that the two persons who had recently found difficulties at the Alien-Office, Mr Bayard and Mr Ogden, were personally known to me, and I could answer for the respectability of their characters— But many others had applied, and would apply, with whom I had no acquaintance, but who would have a right to the same document from me which I might give to my most intimate friends— Mr Beckett took the names of those two Gentlemen, and said that he would not put me to the trouble of giving any other paper than my Passport— He would see that no further difficulty on that account should be made at the Alien-Office— The other subject upon which I spoke to him was that of foreigners, applying to me for Passports to go to America— Also sent to me from the Alien-Office— He said that was because it was intended that no person should go to any Country without the consent of the Minister from that Country— I told him that every body; of every Country had a right to go to America without needing my Consent— I had no right to prevent any one from going— It would be certainly troublesome to me, if I should be required to furnish a document to every foreigner, of every Nation, going from this Country to the United States; but there might be an inconvenience in it, to this Government, for as I could not possibly know all such foreigners, and yet must give the same consent for all who should apply, it was possible applications for pretended foreigners might be made to me, when the person really intending to go might be forbidden by the Laws from leaving this Country— I told him I had put a visa, upon two or three Passports of foreign Ministers here, for persons of their Nation going to America, because they had stated they could not get a Passport from the Alien-Office without it; but I had refused giving Passports of my own to several foreigners, who had none, and one particularly this morning to a Jew, who from his appearance I suspected of having applied for it in reality for another person— Mr Beckett assured me that he would see that this matter should also be duly attended to at the Alien-Office— From thence I went over to Mr Grubb, and took with me several papers to be copied, relating to the Convention, which I requested him to bring me to-morrow Morning.— I returned home and sat down to writing— Mr James Gallatin came and took a Passport for his father and suite; and a separate one for Peter whom he intends to send in the Stage to Liverpool— I soon after received a Note from the British Plenipotentiaries, with their Draft Copy of the Treaty, from which our fair Copy is to be made out. I took it immediately to Mr Clay’s lodgings, and as he was not at home to Mr Gallatin’s— We collated it with the several previous drafts which had been agreed upon, and found it correct. But the Term Treaty, had been used in the preamble drawn up yesterday, and had escaped our attention— It was now in the draft Copy; and Mr Gallatin was desirous of substituting for it the term Convention— Because as the objects of it are limited, and many of the most important objects of a Treaty of Commerce are not included in it, the general denomination of a Treaty of Commerce seems improper for it. We concluded to leave the term in blank, in our copy, and to propose to the British Plenipotentiaries to insert the term Convention, on Monday— The Draft copy names the British Government and Plenipotentiaries first, in the Preamble and throughout the Treaty— I determined to have our Counterpart with the alternative, and shewed to Mr Gallatin the passage in the Instructions from the Secretary of State to me of 13 March, on the subject of the precedence, and order of signatures in the Ghent Treaty— Mr Gallatin still thinks it a matter of no importance— He shewed me his draft of a despatch to the Secretary of State, to be sent with the Treaty— I suggested to him several considerable alterations, to which he readily agreed, and which will shorten the despatch by about one half— It was nearly seven O’Clock when I came home to dinner; and it was so late when we had dined that I had only time for a short walk in the Evening.

2. VI:30. I took a warm bath, in the house on rising this Morning, and then postponed the usual writing of my Journal, to prepare the draft, for our copy of the Treaty. The changes in the order of the parties were in the Preamble—in the first, second, and fifth Articles— I made the draft of them myself, and gave them to Mr Grubb, to be copied, with the draft received from the British Plenipotentiaries— He called
between ten and eleven, and I requested him to have the fair copy made out, and to bring it to me at the latest by eleven O’Clock to-morrow Morning. While he was with me, Mr George Joy came in, and after Grubb went away, remained about two hours here in Conversation— As my opinions differ much from those of Mr Joy, and as I am by nature impatient of contradiction I permitted this Conversation to become too warm on my part— It was interrupted by the coming of Mr Clay, soon after which Mr Joy withdrew. I shewed Mr Clay the note received with the Draft of the Treaty yesterday, from the British Plenipotentiaries— In this Draft I told him they had placed the marks for the Seals (L.S.) three and three in parallel lines by which it appeared that they meant to accede to our proposal as to the order of the signatures— They had also named the British Government and Plenipotentiaries first in the Preamble and throughout the Treaty, which was right for their copy— But at the close they had put, done in Duplicate, which was improper as the Counterparts of a Treaty are never called duplicates, and which might be, for the sake of insisting that there should be no variation between the two Copies— I had however directed that our Copy should be made out taking the alternative throughout the whole Treaty; always naming the American Government and Plenipotentiaries first, but without any change either of substance or in the words. I had ordered the place of the word Treaty to be left in blank, to be filled with Convention, if the British Plenipotentiaries would consent; and I had also directed the word duplicate to be left out, with a blank to insert it if they should insist upon it— Mr Clay did not approve of the change I had ordered to be made; and said he thought I myself had agreed yesterday that it should be only in the preamble— I admitted having said thatit was not so material, in the body of the Treaty; but I had found on referring to the French Copies of the Treaty of Paris of 30. May 1814. that the alternative was also used in the body of the Treaty, and as this was to be a Precedent, I thought it best to make it complete— I then shewed Mr Clay the Instructions from the Department of State to me of 13. March— He said he thought it a matter of no consequence— That Mr Monroe’s argument in the dispatch was a bad one—It was no good reason why we should make a point of such a formality because the European Powers thought it so important— For the most insignificant Powers, such as Spain, for instance, were those that insisted most upon these punctilios— I said this was a point to which all the European Powers always adhered— That I had always regretted that the United States had ever admitted a variation from it— That I had mentioned it to Mr Gallatin at Ghent, and had then forborne to make a point of it, only because we had no Instruction to warrant us in so doing, and because I thought all the Precedents of our Treaties were the other way— This conversation on both sides was perfectly temperate, and good-humoured; and Mr Clay left me— Within half an hour after, Mr Gallatin came in— He shewed me a Note that he had written this morning to Mr Robinson, requesting, that the term Convention might be inserted instead of the term Treaty, so that the American Plenipotentiaries jointly, or I as one of them, might be at liberty to bring forward the other objects of discussion, which we had agreed for the present to postpone— He also shewed me the draft of the dispatch to the Secretary of State, to go with the Treaty; and in which he had made all the alterations that I had proposed— It was a sort of argument in favour of the Treaty which I had requested him to omit, for two reasons—one because if the Treaty was a good one, it needed no argument from us to prove its merits; and the other that in assigning our motives for admitting objectionable parts we referred to circumstances which it would be unnecessary to make known here; which they would be if the dispatch should be published. Mr Gallatin had made the alterations accordingly, though he said they never published the dispatches, when the Negotiation succeeded— I then told him that I had given the Treaty to be copied, and had taken the alternative throughout the whole Instrument— Upon which he said in a peremptory and somewhat petulant manner— “Oh! that is entirely wrong—it will throw the whole business into confusion— Why, you yourself said yesterday it was not necessary in the body of the Treaty”— I said I had observed that it was not so material, in the body of the Treaty—but if the British Plenipotentiaries gave up the point in the Preamble and ratifying clause it was impossible that they should object to the admission of the same principle in the body of the Treaty— I then shewed him the copy of the Treaty of Paris, which I have; printed in France, and in which the King of France is first named in the first Article as well as in the Preamble— He was yet however not satisfied, and asked me if I had told Mr Clay, of the directions I had given for making out our fair copy, and what Mr Clay had said to it— I told him that I had— That Mr Clay disapproved the directions that I had given, as he did, and thought the whole point of no importance— Mr Gallatin then said that I must give the transcriber orders to make out the copy, without any alteration in the body of the Treaty—which I peremptorily refused; and added in a heated and angry manner: “Mr Gallatin, you and Mr Clay may do as you please; but I will not sign the Treaty, without the alternative, observed throughout”— “Now don’t fly off in this manner,[”] said Mr Gallatin— Indeed Sir, said I; I will not sign the Treaty in any other form— I am so far from thinking with Mr Clay that it is of no importance that I think it by much the most important thing that we shall obtain by this Treaty— The Treaty itself I very much dislike, and it is
only out of deference to you and Mr Clay that I consent to sign it at-all— I should infinitely prefer to sign no Treaty at-all, being perfectly convinced that we obtain nothing by it, but what we should obtain by the regulations of this Government without it— Mr Gallatin said that was entirely a different ground, which I admitted to be true; but said it was a sufficient motive for me to insist that the principle of the alternative as to precedence, should be settled completely throughout the Treaty. There would not be a particle of change in the substance, nor even in the words of the two copies— The transpositions were almost all in the second Article— They had all been made by the British Plenipotentiaries themselves, from our Projet, first delivered to them, and which he Mr Gallatin had drawn up— If the British Plenipotentiaries now objected to the transpositions in the second Article, I would propose to them to draw it up, without naming either of the parties, first, but using general expressions applicable to both, as had been done in the corresponding Article of the Treaty of 1806— Mr Gallatin said that the Article of which I spoke was indistinct, and obscure, owing to the use of that very phraseology; and he had for that reason purposely varied from it in drafting the present Article— I said that if Mr Gallatin and Mr Clay chose to have the draft made without any variation in the body of the Treaty, I would immediately take it out of the hands of the transcriber and return it to them. They might then have the Copy made out as they pleased; but I should decline signing it, if it differed from the draft I had ordered to be made— Mr Gallatin left me with a request that I would wait (as I was going to dine out of town) until he could see and consult with Mr Clay, which I promised to do— About half past four, I received a Note from Messrs: Clay and Gallatin, requesting me to send them my copy of the proposed Convention, and also that sent to me by the British Plenipotentiaries, whenever my Copy shall have been completed— We were to dine at Mr Clagett’s at Clapham rise— On the way I stopped at Mr Grubb’s and found that he had not finished in his Copy the second Article of the Treaty— He had also made a mistake, which made it necessary to commence the copy over anew— I requested him to make out the entire copy anew, as I had before directed, and to let me have it by nine O’Clock to-morrow Morning— We then went and dined at Mr Clagett’s at Clapham rise— Besides his own family, there were Mr and Mrs Dunlop, Virginians— Mr Murdoch, Mr Rotch, and Mr Shaw— Mr Clagett is a widower and has ten children—five sons, and five daughters two of whom are married— The eldest daughter, Mrs Kemble was there, with her husband— It was between eleven and twelve at Night, when we came home.

3. VI:30. It was near ten O’Clock this morning when Mr Grubb came with the Copies of the Convention; and that which he had made to be executed by us was precisely conformable to the directions which I had given him— I collated them together, with him, and marked with a pencil on the British draft copy, all the transpositions— I immediately sent over both the Copies to Mr: Clay, and Mr Gallatin, and gave Mr Grubb some other papers to be copied, ready for to-morrow Morning.— Just at eleven Mr Clay came and introduced to me a Mr Murray, a relation of one of the families of that name in New-York. They left me after a short visit and about half an hour afterwards, Mr Gallatin came with the copies of the Convention. He now spoke coolly on the subject of the transpositions, and I was of course usually cool and good-humoured— He said that I had sent the copies so late that it was impossible for Mr Clay and him to have another copy made out in time for the Conference— They were obliged therefore to try the experiment of offering mine— But the British Plenipotentiaries would have the best of the argument on two grounds— One was that he thought by the European usage, the alternative was adopted only when the Governments were named, and was not extended to their Territories and Dominions, and the second was that in the present instance the alternation in the British Copy would not be complete— For there was one clause, which they had inserted in their copy, precisely as he had drawn it up— In that the United States were named first, and they had it so in their copy— My Copy had made no transposition in that clause, so that while our Copy would have the United States first named throughout the Instrument, the British Copy, would in one instance name the United States first also. Whereas if the two copies had been made alike that single clause would have shewn that there was no precedence assumed by Britain in the body of the Treaty. I answered him that I had called yesterday after receiving the Note from Mr Clay and him, upon Mr Grubb expressly to hasten him in making out the copy.— I had urged him and he had promised to let me have it by nine O’Clock this Morning— It was ten however before he came with it; and I had sent it over to them immediately after receiving it— That as to the two grounds of the argument, the transpositions in the second Article were all made by the British Plenipotentiaries themselves, from his draft— He had named the United States first—they had named Great-Britain first— The point therefore was made by them, and not by us— I consented to the transpositions for their copy— I adhered to the original reading for ours. If the use of the alternatives was confined to the naming of the Governments, why had the British Plenipotentiaries made the transitions from his draft? If therefore they urged the argument
it would recoil upon themselves— It was true that they had inserted one clause subsequently drawn up by him, without making the transposition, and had inserted it in their copy, naming the United States first— If they should now desire that the transposition should also be made in that clause, upon their Copy I should readily agree to it— But there was one other passage in which British were named before American Vessels, and which I had left without transposition the same in our copy as in theirs— If they should object to transpositions in the body of the Treaty generally I should propose to make a new draft of the second Article, naming the two parties as such, so that neither should be named first— It was so in the corresponding Article of 1806. which I had examined since he was with me yesterday; and which far from thinking confused and obscure I thought was more clear and distinct than ours, and in much fewer words— He said it was much shorter, but certainly not so precise and intelligible— It was now twelve O’Clock, and we had agreed to meet the British Plenipotentiaries at half past eleven. I went down with Mr Gallatin in his Carriage— Mr Clay whom we overtook in Cavendish Square followed us— At the board of Trade we found only Mr Robinson. He told Mr Gallatin that they agreed to substitute the term Convention instead of that of Treaty— I told him I had also omitted in our copy the terms, “in duplicate[”]— As the Counterparts of the same Treaty were not usually called Duplicates, and I thought the term improper— We had indeed done in triplicates the Treaty of Ghent— But that was because there were three Copies of the Treaty on each side— Mr Gallatin added that if we should now state this Convention to be done in duplicate it would be understood that there were on both sides two Copies.— While we were waiting for Mr Goulburn and Dr: Adams, I recollected that I had left home without taking my Seal— I immediately went in Mr Gallatin’s Carriage, and returned with my Seal. I found on my return the British Plenipotentiaries assembled. We began by collating the copies— Mr Robinson took our Copy as made out by my direction— I took and read the British Copy— Not a word of objection was made by the British Plenipotentiaries to any of the transpositions in our Copy— There were in the British Copy several errors in the Copy— Mr Ellis the Clerk who had made it out was called in, and made the corrections as the errors were noticed— Our copy was correct having been previously collated by Mr Grubb and me this morning— The two copies were then signed and sealed by the Plenipotentiaries on both sides. The three signatures on each side in succession—and those of the two Parties on a line. The American signatures and Seals being first in our Copy— And the British Signatures and Seals first in the British Copy— The alternative was complete, and assented to by the British Plenipotentiaries, without objection— I afterwards observed that it was best to agree upon the title, which we did— I wrote it on a separate piece of paper, to be inserted at the head of our Copy—naming the United States first— Mr Goulburn copied from mine, the title for their Copy, transposing the Order of the parties— The words “in duplicate” were omitted from the British copy as I had proposed— Mr Robinson said that they had readily agreed to use the term Convention instead of that of Treaty; and they should certainly be ready to receive any further proposals or Communications from us, as had been suggested to him in Mr Gallatin’s Note of yesterday, upon the subjects, the discussion of which had been by mutual consent postposned: but it was very possible that if those Subjects were to be discussed, they would not be the persons whom the British Government would appoint for such a negotiation— Mr Gallatin said we had only desired it, that as we had reserved to ourselves the right of bringing forward those Subjects for subsequent discussion, either jointly, or by me, remaining the accredited Minister at this Court, it was to be understood that we did not mean by concluding this Convention upon subjects of minor comparative importance, to abandon that right— Mr: Clay said that we should now the more readily leave the vastly more important objects relating to the belligerent and neutral condition, for future arrangement, as there was the prospect of an immediate termination to the war which has newly arisen, so that the questions most likely to occasion collision would again be dormant— But it was still to be understood that we considered all our claims as left entire. Dr: Adams said that our claims could in no manner be affected by this Convention, as on the other hand none of them were to be understood as admitted by Great-Britain— I observed that in consequence of what had been said by my Colleagues, it might be proper for me to say that it was not my intention to bring forward any further subject for discussions, without new Instructions to that effect form my Government— And that if I should receive such Instructions, I should of course address myself in executing them to the Department of foreign Affairs— With this assurance the British Plenipotentiaries expressed themselves satisfied.— On taking leave of them, Mr Goulburn said to me, well, this is the second good job, we have done together— Yes, said I; and I only hope we may do a third; going on from better to better.— I returned with Mr Gallatin to his lodgings, where Mr Clay soon joined us— As we were coming, Mr Gallatin said, well they got over the transpositions, very easily; but you would not have found it so, if Dr Adams had had the reading of your copy, instead of Robinson— I said that might be.
Immediately after we reached Mr Gallatin’s lodgings, Mr Del Real, and another Gentleman two of the Carthagena deputies came in upon a visit to take leave— Mr Hasler soon afterwards followed— Mr Gallatin dismissed him quite abruptly, telling him that he was very much engaged—and as soon as he was gone, Gallatin said to me, laughing—[“]that is a man of very great merit, though I do treat him so roughly— He was sent by the Government to Europe to procure the Instruments for the general survey of our Coast— But he has outrun his time, and his funds, and his instruments cost £800 more than were appropriated for them, and he is embarassed now about betting back to America— I have engaged Messrs: Baring to advance the monies for the Instruments, and he is to go for his own expences upon his own credit— He has procured an excellent set of instruments— But he is a great politician, though his politics are of the right sort. And he is so great a talker that as we have no time to spare I was obliged to send him away.”— We now signed the joint dispatch to the Secretary of State, to be sent with the Convention, which Mr Gallatin had ready prepared— He and Mr Clay signed their previous joint despatch which they gave to me with the accompanying documents, to have copied, and then transmitted to the United States. Mr Clay, intended to leave town at five O’Clock this afternoon, and Mr Gallatin very early to-morrow Morning— Mr Gallatin told me that he should call upon me this Evening; though it would probably be late, and he requested me not to go to bed, but to have all the papers ready for him. We parted about four O’Clock, and Mr Clay took leave— I returned home and was until dinner employed together with my Son George in making a copy of the joint despatch, the original of which is to go by Mr Gallatin, with the Convention— After dinner I went to Mr: Grubb’s house, with the Convention to have the title inserted in his hand-writing, and to take the copies of all the papers, which he had been making, to go with it— He had nearly but not quite finished the copies— I took a half an hours ride, and on returning to his house found him ready— I left with him to be copied the despatch from Messrs: Clay and Gallatin, with the Documents, and took home with me all the other papers— It was past eleven, when I got home.— I made up the packet for Mr Gallatin, and waited for him until one in the morning. He did not come— I then went to bed— When I came home after signing the Convention I found several Letters; among which one from Mr Fox at Falmouth, enclosing a petition to Lord Sidmouth, from a Captain Hall, master of an American vessel, going from Havre to New-York, from which four Passengers had landed, contrary to the Alien-Act, which had subjected the Captain to a penalty of forty pounds Sterling for each person— The petition was to be released from this penalty, on the ground of ignorance of the Law, which has but very recently been enacted. Mr Fox’s letter to me, was to request me to follow up the petition at the Alien-Office— Mr Charles King, called upon me a few minutes afterwards— He had received a Letter from one of the Passengers requesting him to interest himself and to obtain my interference in their favour— I told Mr King that I would go personally to the Alien-Office upon the subject to-morrow. My engagements this day, preparing for the departure of Mr Gallatin, made it impossible— But I advised him to go to Lord Sidmouth’s Office and speak to him on the subject— I knew Lord Sidmouth would be glad to see him, as he had twice spoken to me of him— He said he knew three of the Passengers who had landed— They were persons of respectable character, and he was quite sure they had landed without knowing that it was contrary to Law— He would go to Lord Sidmouth, and asked my permission to use my name in speaking to him on this matter; which I readily gave him— I had also this day two applications for Passports, which I gave.

4. VII:30. Independence day— Mr Gallatin called upon me this Morning, and apologized for not having come last Night. He said he had dined with Mr Baring, and sat so late with him at table, that he had concluded I should not wait for him— That he was taken quite ill last Night, after he got home, and was still so unwell this morning, that he should not leave town until to-morrow— He now wanted the Packet, containing his and Mr Clay’s dispatch, which I gave last Night to Mr Grubb to be copied— He told me Mr Clay left town early this Morning for Liverpool— He afterwards sent his son James who took the packet containing the dispatches and the Convention, together, with the Letters we had prepared, for America— I delivered this day four Passports— To a Mr Pierson, who produced to me a Passport from Mr Monroe, Secretary of State—to Mr Derkhiem who came with and was introduced to me by Mr George Joy— To Mr Hassler, with his wife and five children, who are returning to America—and to Mr Sanders the Black Man who came from America with my Sons. Mr Hassler is an agent for the American Government, but a native of Switzerland, and not a Citizen of the United States. I promised him that I would call at his lodgings to-morrow Morning, and see his Instruments. At one O’Clock I went to the Office of the Home Department, where I saw Mr Beckett, and spoke to him of Captain Hall’s affair— He had not seen Mr King Yesterday; but he told me the affair was already settled— The alien-officer at Falmouth had written that the Passengers had certainly landed without knowing that it was contrary to the Law, and orders had immediately been sent to discharge them, and allow the vessel to proceed on her voyage. Mr Beckett took the copy of Captain Hall’s Petition to Lord Sidmouth, which I had with me— He said he was then going himself to the Alien-Office,
where he would ascertain that it was the same matter about which the orders had been sent to Falmouth, and he would send me back the copy of the Petition, in the course of the day, which he did. He told me that he had a brother who was going from Liverpool to America, and who he wished might be introduced to Messrs: Clay and Gallatin, if he should chance to go in the same vessel with them. I went over to Mr Grubb, and took away the joint despatch of Messrs: Clay and Gallatin, with its documents which Mr Gallatin requested to have returned to him— I left other papers with Mr Grubb, requesting him to bring me the copies to-morrow Morning— Evening walk in Hyde Park— I received this day from Lord Castlereagh’s Office a Note in answer to mine of 30 June, informing me that orders had been given for the discharge of Anthony Shaddock— My Son John is this day twelve years old— George 5 f. 5 3/4 i. John 4. f 5. i. Charles 3. f 11. i.

5. VII: Mr S. Smith, and Mr Dennie of Boston called upon me, and offered to take Letters for the United States— They are going by the Galen and are to leave town the day after to-morrow Morning. Mr J. B. Murray of New-York came to sollicit an application from me to the British Government, in behalf of the owners of an American Brig, called the Nanina, taken during the late War, within the Spanish Jurisdiction, in a Harbour of Eagle Island, one of the Falkland Islands, while the master and crew of the Nanina, were in the very act of saving the people and property of a British vessel which had been wrecked there— The property saved from the cargo of the wreck was to have been kept by the Master and crew and owners of the Nanina, by way of indemnity for the loss of her voyage. While they were in the process of loading the vessel, a British Sloop of War appeared, captured the Nanina and sent her to Rio de Janeiro. Mr Sumter remonstrated to the Portuguese Government, which declined interfering— To the Spanish Chargé d’Affaires who was to have written to the Spanish Ambassador at London to take the matter up here, on the ground of a violation of the Spanish Jurisdiction— I told Mr Murray that I doubted, whether any application by me to this Government could be of any service to him; but requested him to send me the Papers, and call upon me again to-morrow, at Noon— Mr Beasley came to tell me that he had received a Note from the Transport-Board informing him that Shaddock was discharged. I paid visits to Messrs: C. King, Leavenworth, Ray, Appleton, Hassler, Delprat, Rotch and Gallatin— Mr Ray brought me a Letter of Recommendation from Mr R. King, and Mr Leavenworth, from Mr O. Wolcott. Neither of them, nor Mr Rotch nor Mr Appleton were at home. I found Mr Hassler at the Globe Coffee house in Fleet-Street, and went with him two doors from it and saw the Instruments— Theodolites, Transits, Sextants, and Barometers, at the Maker’s an Optician named Troughton. Hassler said the Instruments were the best that ever were made— I had not the skill to understand or judge of them— They were made of brass, copper, and Silver— I asked Hassler why he had not used Platina instead of Silver— He said it was because the contraction and expansion of silver by the changes of the Atmosphere, corresponded more with those of brass and copper, than did those of Platina. Troughton had however Sextants, with the middle arch of Platina—for which he said he charged two guineas more than for the same kind of Instrument with that arch in Silver—eighteen and twenty guineas. He had engraved the words platina and silver respectively on the instruments which had the arches of those metals— They are so much alike to external appearance, that before he adopted the expedient of thus marking them, some of the East-India Officers who had purchased of him the Sextants with Silver Arches, sold them for those with arches of Platina— So, said he, I have spoiled their trade. He shewed me the division lines in squares under the eye glasses of his telescopes, made of a thread of a Spiders web— The inventor of which, he told me, was an American—Dr: Rittenhouse. I asked him whether they were thinner than metallic wire could be drawn. He said three times thinner than the most attenuated wire— I enquired whether they were as durable— He said he had Instruments which had been thirty years in use, with the Spider’s thread yet entire. It was far more elastic than wire.— He also shewed me by an experiment, a very perceptible fall of the mercury in one of his Barometers by taking it up from the third to the fourth Story of his house; an elevation of only eleven feet. He said that an elevation even of the length of the Barometer caused a perceptible fall. Mr Hassler goes with all these Instruments in a vessel to New-York— I found Mr Delprat at home at the London Coffee-house, and much engaged upon his commercial affairs— On my return home, I called upon Mr Gallatin, who is yet unwell— I had taken with me the papers which at his request I had withdrawn from Mr Grubb, but he now told me I might keep them— He said if he should go to Liverpool and embark with Mr Clay, they would have time enough to make another copy of their despatch on their passage; but if he should not find himself better to-morrow, he would not go to Liverpool at-all— There was a vessel to sail from this Port, in nine days, and he would take passage in her— In that case I should have time before he sailed to get the copies made out, and could then return to him the despatch— I had some further Conversation with him respecting the wish of the Secretary of the Treasury, to sell the three Millions of Certificates of Stock which he sent us last September; and said that Mr Baring had told him that no funds had yet been sent for the payment due on the Louisiana Stock, here and in Holland on the first of this Month— That it was not publicly known, only
because by the private arrangements of the Bankers in Holland with the Stock-holders there, the interest was paid annually there, on the first of January— Mr Gallatin made several calculations, from all which it resulted that the Stock could not be sold either here or in Holland at ninety-five per Cent.— I was just taking leave of him, when Mr Bagot came in, and said he had been calling at my lodgings to see me. He had received a note from Mr Planta, Lord Castlereagh’s Secretary, mentioning his Lordship’s wish that Mr Bagot would be prepared to sail for America as soon as he should find it convenient.— Mr Planta added that he had suggested to Lord Castlereagh Circumstances of a domestic nature, in Mr Bagot’s family, which might render it inconvenient for him to go at present— Lord Castlereagh had said that his departure might be deferred, if the delay could be explained to me in a manner which would be satisfactory to the American Government— Mr Bagot said that his wife was to be confined about the 15th: of September— He had consulted his physician, who had told him she must not go, before her confinement— They would certainly be ready to sail by the first week in October— If on public considerations it should be necessary that he should go now, he would certainly go; but if it could be made agreeable to the American Government that his departure should be postponed for this occasion, it would be a great relief to him. I said that so far as related to the point of etiquette, I would answer for it that the delay should be explained entirely to the satisfaction of the American Government— As to public business, I had not the means of knowing how that might be affected by the delay.— Lord Castlereagh had told me there was a voluminous Correspondence received from Mr Baker, upon Subjects which I understood related to the Execution of the Treaty.— I did not know how far that might continue to be managed by Mr Baker, or might require the presence of Mr Bagot. That he could easily ascertain, and could shape his course accordingly— He said he would make the enquiries at the foreign Office, and see me about it again— Mr Gallatin concurred in the opinions I had given to Mr Bagot, and after he was gone, we agreed that there was no necessity for hurrying his departure— Mr Gallatin said that this Government never gave any powers to their Ministers in America— That all the business between the two Governments had always been transacted here— On returning home I found a note from Mr Alexander Baring, with a packet for me, and a Letter to the Brothers Baring from the Secretary of the Treasury— The packet contained Instructions to me of 23. May to make sale at the market price in London, of the Certificates of Stock sent last September by Mr Boyd, in sufficiency to raise 246000 dollars for the payment of the interest on the Louisiana loan due here, and in Holland on the first of this month— Mr Baring proposes to see me any morning at my convenience after twelve O’Clock.

6. VI:15. Mr Murray sent me last Evening all the papers relative to the capture of the Nanina, and I read them over— He called upon me again this day at Noon— I told him that if there was any remedy for them in the case, of which I entertained some apprehension, it must be, by a Memorial addressed to this Government— I supposed to the Lords of the Admiralty— There appeared to me no foundation after the Peace, upon which I could make an Official Application, relating to it here.— He shewed me a Letter, which by Order of the Government of the United States, Mr Beasley had written to the Spanish Ambassador here, demanding redress for the violation of the Spanish Territorial Jurisdiction— But it is evident that this claim is in the first instance to the Government of Spain— Mr Murray said, that Admiral Dixon had offered to give up the Nanina, at Rio de Janeiro— So I had seen by the Papers; and that the offer had been accepted by the Captain— It did not appear why it was not carried into effect, and I regretted that it had not been— We were interrupted by other visitors— Mr Murray concluded to present his memorial to the Lords of the Admiralty, and I told him it would give me pleasure if I could be of any assistance to him in promoting the object of his application— I received from Mr John Prince junr: a Letter requesting me to claim of this Government, restitution of a Vessel belonging to him and his brother in Law John Derby, which at the breaking out of the late War happened to be in an English Port, and was detained and afterwards condemned.— He encloses a Decree of Judge Davis’s Judge of the United States District Court of Massachusetts, dismissing a libel against British property under similar Circumstances. I had visits from a Mr Hoffman of Baltimore to ask a Passport for his brother who is at Liverpool, and from Mr J. F. Dana, who brought me a Letter of Recommendation from Mr A. H. Everett— He comes on a Commission from Harvard University to procure a philosophical and chemical Apparatus for that Seminary.— I called upon Mr Gallatin, and found him packing his trunks to take his departure for Liverpool— He said he should go in an hour from that time. He had found his complaint was only a severe cold, and as he knew how to manage that he would not wait here any longer— I went down to the Counting house of the Brothers Baring, and had some Conversation with Mr Alexander Baring, respecting the last Instructions from the Secretary of the Treasury.— He proposed that I should send for the Certificates of the Stock, which are in the hands of Mr Jackson at Paris, and that I should write to Messrs: Willink and Van Staphorst at Amsterdam, and ask of them a power to transfer— I urged upon Mr Baring to undertake the sale of the whole— He said he should make an offer for the whole, of about ninety— Calculating then to dispose of the whole at 95. This was
the margin, upon which they always reckoned in their bargains with this Government— I told him that the American Stocks were rapidly rising in America— They must continue to rise— The embarrassment of the Government was momentary— The Revenue would now be flowing in abundantly— I believed the Stocks would soon be at par. He said the margin was not great—only from 90 to 100, but he thought the rise would not be within two or three years. There was a large amount of Treasury-Bills, to be withdrawn from circulation, and the payment of the principal of the Louisiana loan, would begin in the year 1818— Mr Baring agreed to call at my lodgings at ten O’Clock to-morrow Morning, when I promised to shew him the form of the Certificates standing in the names of Messrs: Willink’s and Van Staphorst’s and which are to be sold. On my return home I stopped to see Mr Ogden and Mr Bayard, to enquire when Mr Ogden intended to leave town for France— He spoke of Saturday next, but with some uncertainty— While I was there, Mr Gore came in— He is going to America, as the civil Governor of Upper Canada— Ogden said he believed he was going out with a strong conviction that in a very few years his Government must become a part of the United States— I walked after dinner in the Park.

7. VI:30. Mr Alexander Baring called upon me this morning at ten O’Clock, and we had some further Conversation together concerning the sale of the Certificates of Stock— We found upon examining the copy of the form of Certificate which I have, that the interest is expressly made payable semi-annually at Amsterdam— Mr Baring said that a Power to transfer, by Messrs: Willink & Van Staphorst, would therefore not be sufficient, because the Stock, with the Interest payable at Amsterdam, would not be saleable here— I asked him if the transfer could not be taken, with an engagement from me, or in the Confidence that the alteration would be made at the Treasury Department, so as to make the Interest payable here; of which there could be no possible doubt, as it would be much more for the convenience of the Treasury; and it had been made in the Certificates payable at Amsterdam only for the sake of making it more saleable there. Mr: Baring said it would perhaps still be best to endeavour to make the sale of it there— At all Events, the Bills which the Secretary of the Treasury had authorised the Bankers at Amsterdam to draw upon his house, should be paid. He would consult with his partners, and perhaps he would make an offer for the whole Stock; upon the Condition that no more of it should be brought into the market by the United States. He would also write to the House of Hope’s at Amsterdam, and see whether they, by associating themselves with the Willink’s & Van Staphorst’s could not accomplish the sale of the Stock there— I told him it would doubtless be a great accommodation to our Treasury if it could be effected— For independent of this payment, we had now a Squadron in the Mediterranean, and I thought it highly probable that there would be a necessity of supplying them by Bills upon London— Mr Baring took the Copy of the Certificate of Stock, with him, and promised to make me his proposals at an early day.— He mentioned to me the Accounts of the Surrender of Paris by a Military Convention, on the 3d: instant, and the sudden and Extraordinary death of Mr Whitbread, who yesterday morning cut his own throat with a Razor— I called upon Mr Beasley, to ask him for Copies of some papers concerning the affair of the Prisoners at Dartmoor.— Wrote a short Letter upon the subject to the Secy: of State— I took a long walk in the Streets before dinner, and lost myself so as to be nearly an hour belated— The Children passed the Evening with Mr Sanders at his lodgings, and I took a ride with Mrs: Adams twice round the ring in Hyde Park.

8. VI:15. Looking over my papers this Morning, I found a Letter for Messrs: A. Glennie and Son, together with a Bottomry Bond, to be delivered to them, which were sent to me by Mr Hottinguer on the day that I left Paris— They should have been delivered immediately upon my arrival here; but had entirely escaped my recollection. I immediately went into the City, to the Counting House of Messrs: Glennie and Son, and delivered the papers to them, taking their receipt for the Bond according to Mr Hottinguer’s request. I accounted and apologized to them for the delay of the delivery, which had occasioned no other inconvenience than their being left sometime in uncertainty what had become of the Bond. They had made enquiries, some time since by a friend of theirs who went to Paris, and had received within these two or three days the information that it had been entrusted to me— They gave me a Letter from Mr Norman, dated in April which they have had some time in their hands.— From them, I went over to Mr Grubb, to whom I took a number of Papers to be copied. I also compared with him those that he had in readiness, which took us an hour and a half— I requested him to bring me the copy of the Convention, and of the Papers to be sent with it, on Monday Morning; but he told me he wished to go out of town with his wife to-morrow, and I gave him till Tuesday Morning to finish the Copies— When I came home I found that Mr Bagot had called while I was out; and Mr Samuel Torrey of Boston, who came for a Passport for himself and his wife, (a daughter of Mr Ignatius Sargent) to return to the United States, in consequence of the sudden death of his father. He left a Letter, requesting to have the Passport immediately, and I sent it to his lodgings— I had a visit from Mr George H. Apthorp who has just returned from India, and is going immediately to Holland. He went about two years since from this place to Java, with two Ships, under English Colours— The first that were fitted out on private account, since the New Charter of the
East-India Company; and has just returned with two Cargoes of Coffee, which he has obtained permission to carry and unlade in Holland. He says that the American trade to India, is so valuable and so important to the British establishments there, that he is fully convinced it will never be prohibited by the British Government— I took a long walk with George this Evening, in Hyde Park.

9. VI:30. This was I think the first day since I have been in London, which has passed away without an interruption and without a visitor. I wrote to Mr Erving at Paris, to have the Letter in readiness whenever the opportunity for sending it may occur— George and John went with Mr Sanders to Church at the White Hall Chapel, after finding that there was no performance of Public Worship, at St. James’s Chapel— They were greatly annoyed, on seeing at Whitehall, the American Standards taken during the late War— I went with Mrs Adams and paid visits to Mr and Mrs Hare and Mr Rawle of Philadelphia— To Mr Bourke the Danish Minister and his Lady, and to Mr and Miss Bond, and Miss Travis— We found nobody at home, but Miss Travis— We afterwards took a ride in the Park, where the number of Carriages going in procession is very much diminished— The fashionable season is just finishing— I took a short walk before dinner, and walked again after dinner, with the three boys, to and in the Regent’s Park.

10. VI: Mr Celestin de Pontalba, a native of New-Orleans came this morning for a Passport—for himself and his family—going to France. A Mr Beck of Pennsylvania came also for a Passport. Mr Mallison and Captain Johnson occupied me also about two hours— Mallison is an inventor of a sort of Cork Jacket called by him a Seamen’s Friend, to save men from drowning— He has obtained from Parliament a sum of one hundred pounds Sterling, not, he alledges as a reward but to defray his expences in the experiments to prove the efficacy of his invention— He has been applying to Parliament for further encouragement—petitioning that every ship in the royal navy might be furnished with a number of the Seamen’s Friends. But as the Lords of the Admiralty discountenance the application the House of Commons has been inexorable to his petition. Mr Mallison therefore comes to me, to offer his Seamen’s Friends for the benefit of the American Navy— He has sent me two of his pamphlets containing his demonstration of the superior merit of his invention, and his correspondence with the Admiralty Board here whom he has been unable to convince. I told him I had no authority to make a contrast for furnishing the American Navy with his Seamen’s Friends— That I could not undertake to judge between him who argued ingeniously that his was the best of inventions for saving persons from drowning, and Mr Croker the Secretary to the Lords of the Admiralty, who had told the House of Commons that of fifty-two inventions for the same purpose presented to the Admiralty Board, this was the worst.— That if any American ships of War should come to England, the Captains might perhaps be authorized to furnish them with a suitable number of his Seamen’s Friends, if they thought them useful, and I knew of no other manner by which the American Navy could be supplied with them— He said that he should renew his application here, the next Session of Parliament—to the House of Lords— But as he could not much expect success for any thing that was opposed by any one of his Majesty’s Ministers, if he failed then, he should abandon all further attention to the subject— The occasional sale of his Seamen’s Friends, not being sufficiently profitable to compensate him for the time and expence that he bestowed upon them— Captain Johnson’s project is upon a larger scale than Mr Mallison’s— He promises nothing less than to destroy the whole Algerine fleet, by submarine explosion. Captain Johnson brought this morning a draft of the Memorial, by which he makes this offer— He claims no pay, grant, or pecuniary assistance until he shall have accomplished his work; but only to receive half the value at a fair estimate of the ships that he shall destroy— I made for his Consideration several observations upon the terms of his proposal which I thought might be liable to objections, and he took it away with him to make such alterations in it as he should think advisable— Captain Johnson who says he is the depository of all Mr Fulton’s plans; and who says he has improved upon Fulton’s Torpedo-system to such a degree that he can fix a torpedo, at the bottom of any vessel in spite of any defence that she can make, has long been urging his schemes upon the British Government, and says he told the Duke of York, who is his friend that if this Government would not purchase his secret he would offer it through me to the American Government— But among his proposals was that he should go with a ship of his own; but commissioned by the American Government, and totally independent of the Authority of any Officer, of the American Navy. I pointed out to him the inconveniences, and impracticabilities of this proposal— That he must be commissioned there was no doubt— But by our Laws his crew must be Americans, and he could not be commissioned in our Navy, without being subject to the regulations of the Navy, and of course subjected to the authority of the Superior Officers with whom he would have to co-operate— He said his only object was that he might keep his machinery free from inspection; that he had been exposed to that inconvenience here, by being placed under the authority of Officers, who would order him away from his ship, and then have his machinery examined according to their own pleasure. He would sell his secret itself if the American Government would purchase it, but if not he must be allowed to guard himself against the inspection of his machinery.— I distrust Captain Johnson’s project, precisely because it promises too much— Mr Murray came and introduced to me a Mr Hall of New-York— Mr Murray said his uncle was occupied upon a Memorial to the Lords of the Admiralty, upon his claim,
which he would shew me, when prepared; and he intimated a wish to see personally some of the Lords of the Admiralty concerning it. Mr Hall came to enquire concerning the rights of the Children of Mr Thomas Mullett deceased to his portion of the grant made by Act of Congress to the Claimants of the Yazoo-Lands— Mr Mullett’s only son Frederick is a Bankrupt—he left three daughters, two of whom are married, and one is a widow— The Assignees of Frederick Mullett claim the whole, on his supposed right of sole heir, or at least a double portion, as the only Son— There was a Will made by Mr Mullett; but not being attested, it is a nullity here, and as I told Mr Hall in America— I told Mr Hall that the grant for the release of the Yazoo claims was certainly personal Estate, and as such must be distributed equally between the four Children— Even if it were real Estate, I believed that by the Laws of Georgia, the distribution would be the same— All the children must release, and all take the grant in equal portions— The time for making the release was limited to the first of January this year—the Act of Congress having passed the 8th: of March 1814— But in this particular case the Commissioners had allowed a further extension of time. Mr Hall enquired whether I had any objection to stating my opinion in writing— I declined it as being a mere law question upon which I did not mean to give a professional and responsible answer— He asked me if I would give it verbally if one of the Assignees should call upon me— I said I would— Mr Wilberforce paid me a visit, and expressed to me his high satisfaction at the restoration of Peace between our two Countries— He spoke about an abusive Article in the quarterly Review against America, concerning which he had received from America, letters from two Gentlemen, one of them enclosing an Answer to it which he had not had time to read. He found the Article was ascribed to Mr Canning; he thought erroneously; and he should write to Canning about it— I said the Review was represented as being under the Patronage of Mr Canning—but the Article, in two pamphlets answering it, which I had received from America, was ascribed to Mr Southey, who had however denied being the author of it, in a Letter, published in a late Courier. I explained to Mr Wilberforce the manner in which the friends of Great-Britain in America were affected, by such publications as that Article in the Quarterly Review— He said that he lamented it—but that those were not the general sentiments of this Nation, and that the Quarterly Review itself was a work of limited Circulation— Much more limited than that of the Edinburgh Review— I had Conversation with Mr Wilberforce upon various other topics, and proposed to call upon him; but he said he was going into the Country for the Summer— The day was thus consumed until half an hour before dinner time; when I took a short walk; and a longer one after dinner with my three sons in the Regent’s Park.

11. VI:15. The forty-eighth year of my life has closed; and I this day enter upon the forty-ninth. It has in relation to Public Affairs been the most important year of my Life, and in my private and domestic relations one of the most happy years. May I be duly sensible of the hand from which the blessings have flowed; duly humble in prosperity, duly prepared for adversity, and enabled more fully and faithfully to discharge all my duties than I have been hitherto— I had this day a constant succession of Americans applying for Passports, of which I delivered six. I received from Mr Chester the Assistant Master of the Ceremonies a Notification that the Prince Regent would go to-morrow at two O’Clock, to close the Session of Parliament. And that if I wished to attend I must go in Habit habillé, and be at the house of Lords about a quarter before two. I received letters from Mr Ingraham, and from Commodore Barney at Plymouth— Barney landed there on the 8th: from the American ship Virgin from Baltimore, with dispatches from the Government to Mr Bayard, Mr Gallatin and myself— But was detained there by the Collector of the Customs, under the regulations of the Alien Act. I wrote immediately a Note to Mr Beckett requesting him to give directions that Mr Barney may be permitted to proceed immediately to London, and suggesting the expedience of some general order, by which messengers, charged with public despatches to or from the Minister of the United States may not be subjected to detention. For greater precaution I took this Note to the Home Department, and afterwards to the Alien-Office, myself— Mr Beckett however was not to be found at either— After waiting some time, as he did not return, I left the Note for him at the Home Department— I paid visits to Mr Bagot at Mr Wellesley-Pole’s, from whence I found he had removed to another place— He was not at home and I left a Card. I also went to two Houses to find Admiral Tchitchagoff, but had been misinformed as to the place of his lodgings, and did not find him— Visits from the Chevalier de Freire, the Portuguese Minister, and his Lady. From Messrs: Carnes, Kittera, Dexter (a Son of Dr: Dexter of Boston) Knap, O’Brien, and Roth, Americans who came for Passports. I wrote to Messrs: Willinks and Van Staphorst’s at Amsterdam— After dinner I took a ride with all my family to Kensington Garden— We all walked in the Garden, and I with George and Charles, walked home. I am anxious to give the boys exercise, and the freshest air that can be breathed in this Metropolis— The Parks and Kensington Garden, are substantially in the Country— I was highly gratified this afternoon by an Article in the Courier, headed Victory of the Americans over the Algerines; and stating that Commodore Decatur’s
Squadron, had taken on the 20th: of June, and carried into Carthagena, the Algerine frigate Mazoura, of 40 Guns, commanded by the Admiral of Algiers, who was killed; that the next morning another frigate was driven ashore, and the crew had abandoned her, and taken refuge on the land, where they were pursued and taken up by the Spanish Peasants—and that a corvette was pursued by our Squadron and would probably be taken— I had received yesterday a Letter from Mr Shaler and Commodore Decatur, dated off Cadiz 13. June—informing me that they were Commissioners to treat of Peace with Algiers, and should proceed thither immediately.

12. V:45. Visits from Mr C. King, with Mr Irving of New-York, a brother of the Gentleman who was last year at New-York.— From Mr Bagot— From Mr Perry and Mr Rogers, who came for Passports— Mr Bagot told me that he had finally concluded to go, to America, without waiting for Mrs: Bagots’s confinement— There was a medical man in whom she had great confidence, who was going out with them. He had been to Bruxelles to attend her Sister, Lady Fitzroy Somerset, and having by that absence been loosened somewhat in this practice, he had consented to go with them to America, and return when he could send him back— I went to the House of Lords, and was there at a quarter before two, the time mentioned in Mr Chester’s Note— The Duke’s of York and Kent, were there, in their Robes as Peers—a very small number of the other Peers, most of the foreign Ambassadors and Ministers, and a house full of Ladies as Spectators— The Prince Regent came in, with Royal State, precisely at two. He had the Royal and Regent’s Crown’s born upon Cushions before him; but was in a military uniform, with a multitude of Orders, and over them the Robes of a Peer— He wore his Hat, and took his Seat upon the Throne. The Speaker of the House of Commons in his wig and black gown, together with a few members of the house, all dressed in black appeared at the Bar of the House, immediately after the Regent was seated, and made a speech addressed to him, which he concluded by presenting to him a bill for raising six millions for the service of his Majesty— That and several other Bills were read by their titles, and when the Prince by a nod had expressed his Assent to them, a Clerk pronounced in very bad French the words Le Roi le veut, to some, and soit fait comme il est desiré to others— After which the Prince Regent read his Speech, and then the Lord Chancellor who stood behind the Prince, and at his right hand declared the Session of Parliament to be prorogued to the 22d: of August— The Prince then rose and withdrew— Mr Chester told me that the Queen had been in Town yesterday only for an hour, and probably would not come to town again before the Winter— After the Prince was gone, I saw Lord Gambier, who was there, but not in his Robes as a Peer— He was in a plain frock dress. He introduced me to Lord Bathurst, to whom I apologized for not having called upon him— I was also introduced to Count Munster the Hanoverian Minister, who has just returned from the Continent— The Spanish and Dutch Ambassadors, and the Portuguese and Sardinian Ministers spoke to me of the reported capture by our Squadron, of the Algerine frigate— Lords Bathurst and Gambier also mentioned it. The Dutch Ambassador told me that he was informed of it by a Letter from the Dutch Minister at Madrid— The Spanish Ambassador asked if our Squadron had entered the Port of Cadiz— I said I believed they had not— He asked if they had attempted to enter— I did not know— He seemed to doubt whether it would be admitted, and intimated that there was a state of hostility between Spain and the United States— I said it seemed by the account received here that our ships had been admitted at Carthagena— I asked him what was the state of Relations, between Spain and Algiers— He answered that it was also between Peace and War— He said he had not any late Communication from his Court respecting the United States; but the last that he had received mentioned that the Spanish Minister sent to the United States had not been recognized— I said I believed he had been recognized since the Restoration of the king, but that a Minister had been appointed by our Government to Spain, whom the king of Spain had refused to receive— He said that was because the Spanish Minister in the United States was not recognized— From the substance of his Conversation I am not without concern that Decatur may meet with some difficulty there— I came home about three, and wrote until dinner time— In the Evening we rode to Kensington Garden, and left the Boys to play bat and Ball in the Park while we walked round the Garden— The walk was so much longer than we had expected, that Mrs Adams was excessively fatigued, when we got back— I received the answer from Mr Beckett to my Note of Yesterday, respecting Commodore Barney; who he says was improperly detained by the Collector of the Customs at Plymouth— He does not answer my suggestion for a general order to exempt public messengers from detention.

13. V. Mr Grubb called upon me about nine this morning with the Papers which he has copied, we collated those of them which had not been before examined, and I gave him all the remaining papers to be copied into the Letter Book— This employed more than two hours which delayed my breakfast until almost Noon— I had scarcely finished that, when Mr George Joy came, and sat with me two hours longer. Americans and foreigners of all Nations going to America still come in multitudes for Passports or Certificates to enable them to obtain Passports at the Alien-Office. I gave two Passports and Certified one from the Department of State, for Americans— A Savoyard, a Swiss and a Hollander came for Certificates— A Mrs Lynn, came with a Bond for an annuity of £50. Sterling a year upon a penalty of £500. given her by a man named George Hogarth, now living and wealthy as she said, in Maryland, to whom she had fallen an early sacrifice, and by whom she had had five children— The annuity had been paid for several years by Mr James Brookes, but is now ten years in arrear,
she wishes to go to America, to recover it, and came to me for a Passport— As she is a British Subject I could not give her one, and she needs none— A Sailor, named Alexander Downey came to ask assistance from me to enable him to return to America— He came yesterday with a number of others, but I could not then see them— He says there are many of them—he believes nearly two hundred who were taken in India; sent from thence to England, and upon their arrival here, about a fortnight since, discharged— That they have repeatedly applied at Mr Beasley’s Office, but have not been able to see him, and he has absolutely refused to give them any assistance or relief— That there are a number of American Vessels here, the Masters of which would each take three or four of them if Mr Beasley or I would give them orders to that effect— I told him that it was altogether Mr Beasley’s Office and not mine— That he must go again to-morrow to Mr Beasley, whom I would see in the interval, and I would do what I could to prevail upon Mr Beasley to get them passages home— A Mrs: Speck, stating herself to be the widow of a Master of a vessel belonging to New-York, who was lost two years ago at sea, came also to obtain the means of returning to America— She says she came over here last September, upon the invitation of some of her relations, with four children all under eleven years of age— But her relations give her now no assistance, and she has no means of supporting herself and her children but working at making Straw hats, which is only during the Summer, and by which she cannot earn more than sixteen Shillings a week— Her father and brother are at Charleston South Carolina, where she wishes to go, or to New York— I told her that I could give her a Passport for herself and her family; but I could not undertake to pay the expence of their passage— I advised her to enquire, for some Lady who might be going, and who might want an attendant, and would thus provide a passage for her— She said she would make enquiries and call here again— Mr Wilson, a man whom we saw last Autumn at Ghent, came and had a quantity of Pennsylvania paper currency, issued 10. April 1775, and he came to enquire whether the British Government were not obliged to pay it, because it was issued in the name of the royal authority— I gave him a History of the Paper currency of our Revolutionary War, and of the forgeries of the Paper which were issued on the royal side— The paper that he produced had the appearance of being among the forgeries— He said this paper had been paid at the time by Andrew Allen, for a landed Estate in Pennsylvania— And he enquired if I knew where Mr Allen was to be found— I said I believed he was dead; but his Son might be in this Country, and probably Mr Bond formerly the British Consul General in America, could inform him where he was to be found— Mr Wilson as he went away reminded me that he had escaped last Summer from this Country, by breaking his Parole— He said he afterwards went to France, and sailed from Bordeaux in February, for the United States— He has now returned in the Panther, from Boston to Liverpool, and says they made the land in thirteen days— Mr Bray, the Son in Law of Mr S. Elliot of Boston came in the same vessel, and the day before yesterday brought me Letters from my father and mother— My visitors confined me at home this day till dinner time— In the Evening I walked round Hyde-Park, while the boys were playing in it. I received a Letter from Mr Hazard, now Consul of the United States at Antwerp, complaining of a case of Impressment, by a British Officer in that Port—another from three Americans at Dover landed from Calais, and detained under the regulations of the Alien-Law— I wrote to Mr Beckett requesting that their permission to come to London might be immediately dispatched.— This Evening I received a Note from Mr Hamilton, Under-Secretary of State in the Department of foreign Affairs; enquiring whether Mr Beasley, is now acting here as Consul of the United States.

14. V:45. I sent early this morning to Mr Beasley, requesting him to call upon me, before he should go into the City— When he came, I gave him the Letter that I received yesterday, respecting the impressment of a Seaman from an American Vessel, by a British Officer in the Port of Antwerp, and two other Letters from Sailors, alledging that they are Americans, and have been impressed— Requesting him to make the proper Applications for their release— I also mentioned to him the case of the Seamen, who have been sent here as Prisoners of War, from India, and discharged here— And I proposed to him to send them home by one of the Cartels, which have arrived here, from America, and found all the Prisoners that were at Plymouth, already gone. He said he would make enquiries to ascertain what number there is of these Prisoners from India, and take proper steps in consequence to send them home. But he complained of the impositions practiced by many Sailors, who were continually coming to him to demand relief, and who would neither work, nor go on board vessels by which he had obtained for them passages to America— I enquired of him the means of writing to Gibraltar; and of the earliest opportunities of vessels going from this Port to the United States. He promised to obtain the information, and let me know this Evening or to-morrow Morning— He also mentioned to me a mode of sending parcels by the Mail Coach to Liverpool, of which I may in future avail myself.— I delivered three Passports for Americans, going to the United States, and several Visas on the Passports of foreign Ministers— A Mr Cox an Englishman who was married by Bishop White, at Philadelphia in 1792—came to enquire if I could authenticate the Bishop’s signature to the Certificate of the Marriage— He said he
he was about placing his Son, at a College at Oxford, and as he was descended from the founder of the College, he was entitled to several privileges, which it was of importance to secure to him— He could trace and prove his pedigree very clearly to the foundation of the College, in the reign of James the first— But it would be necessary to have the authentication of Bishop White’s Certificate of his own Marriage. And he must have it by the 5th: or at latest the 6th: of August— The entrance of his Son at College, being to take place on the 7th. Not being myself acquainted with Bishop White’s hand-writing, I referred Mr Cox to Mr Bond, who having long resided at Philadelphia, might probably know it, and to Mr and Mrs Hare, and Mr Rawle of Philadelphia, who are now here— I went with Mrs Adams and paid visits to the Portuguese Minister, and his Lady, who were not at home—to Lady Carysfort; but they are gone into the Country; and to Mr and Mrs Trumbull who received us. They expect to sail next week in the Illinois for New-York— Trumbull gravely told me that the French Officers in Paris last year had hired the fencing Masters of their Regiments, and dressed themselves up as Officers, to insult the Russian Officers and kill them in Duels— And that not less than five hundred Russian Officers were killed in such Duels.— I came home and finished a Letter to the Secretary of State. I hoped to have sent off a Packet for him this Evening to Liverpool, but I could not have it prepared in time— After dinner Mrs Adams and the two younger boys took a Ride—and George and I walked to Hyde Park, and round the ring which encircles it— The ring is a circle of two miles, and a few rods— The distance from our lodgings to the Park is one Mile.

15. VI:15. My arrears are once more retrieved. At the close of the last Month, and the beginning of the present the urgency of my occupations was so great that I was obliged to devote to other objects the morning hours which I apply habitually to this Journal, while at the same time it lengthened the record of every day— This is the essential difficulty of keeping a Journal and must render it impracticable to keep it in detail, when the occupations are constantly surcharged— Commodore Barney arrived this Morning, and brought me a small packet of despatches from the Secretary of State— He also gave me one for Mr Bayard, which must be returned to the United States. Those to myself give me ample cause for Reflection, and for exertion.— Mr Dexter came to inform me that he expected to embark early next week for Boston. Mr Hall and Mr Bolton, Citizens of Georgia came with him, for Passports— Mr Greuhm the Prussian Chargé d’Affairs came, and referring to a despatch which he had received from his Government, said it was their desire to give new activity and extension to their relations with the United-States— The despatch mentioned the commercial Treaty of 1799. which being only for ten years had of course expired— There was now only one Prussian Consul in America—Mr Steinmetz; at Charleston South-Carolina. He enquired whether any difficulty would occur by the American Government, in the admission of Consuls in other Ports— Mr Ralph B. Forbes had applied to be appointed the Prussian Consul in Boston, and he shewed me a list of the Ports which he had made out where he thought Consuls might be useful— They were Boston, Newport, New-York, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Norfolk, Savannah and New-Orleans— I told him that I could assure him without hesitation that wherever the Prussian Government should think proper to appoint Consuls in the United States, they would be received without difficulty by the American Government. The Consular Establishment was sanctioned by the ordinary Law of Nations, and although it was customary to insert an Article in Commercial Treaties for their admission, and the manner in which they are considered, we conceived no such Stipulation as necessary, and received as freely the Consuls of Nations with which we had no Treaty as of those with which we had— It was however to be observed that in both cases we considered Consuls, as amenable to the Laws of the Country where they exercised their Offices. I requested him however to send me a minute in writing of the substance of what he said to me, and I would communicate it to the Government of the United States— He promised accordingly to send me a note. I wrote a short Letter to the Secretary of State, acknowledging the receipt of his despatches by Commodore Barney, and one to Mr Maury at Liverpool, to whom I enclosed all the despatches which I have prepared, and the Newspapers— I took the whole down to Mr Beasley’s Office, N. 10. Austin Friars, and left it to be sent as a parcel, by the Mail Coach this Evening for Liverpool.— Mr Ogden had come and informed me that he should go to-morrow Morning for Paris— On my return from the City, I stopped at the London Coffee-House, and left a Letter for him to take. After dinner I walked with George in the Regents Park— I received a Note from Lord Viscount Hampden requesting me to appoint a time, when I would see him.— I answered the Note, appointing one O’Clock to-morrow or on Monday, as might best suit his own convenience.

16. VI. Received this day four Letters. 1. From Commodore Barney at his lodgings N. 12 Blenheim Street. He was so unwell as to be unable to come out— 2. From Mr Baring; containing his proposals respecting the sale of the Certificates of Stock— 3. From Mr Logan, a Projector, who has already assailed me, with pamphlets, Letters and Visits— 4. From Mr C. Hughes at Baltimore.— Given me by Commodore Barney; whom I visited at his Lodgings, and found at dinner— Mr Sanders called, and went with the boys to Church. Mr Hare, and Mr Rawle, paid us visits; I found we were mistaken in the belief that Mrs Hare was here with her Husband— The interruptions this day were so few, that I wrote a long Letter to my Mother, and walked before dinner to the Park-gate; and after dinner with Mrs Adams, and all the boys, to and round the Regent’s Park. We met Mr Hewlett walking with two Ladies, but did not speak to him. Commodore Barney shewed me a Letter from Mr Clay, at Liverpool, dated the 13th.—last Thursday. He and Mr Gallatin had taken the Cabin of the
ship Lorenzo, bound to New-York, and were to sail on Friday or Saturday last. Mr Hughes writes me that he hears a Major M’Pherson is to be appointed the Secretary to this Legation.

17. VI:15. Mr John Atkinson came with the Papers which had been acknowledged by his Uncle Francis Atkinson before me on the 24th. of June, and which I now signed and sealed. In the Gazette of last Saturday Evening there is a notice that R. G. Beasley Esqr is permitted to act as Consul General of the United States of America, until the arrival of his Successor. This morning Captain Grover came and asked me for a Passport for himself to go to France— I told him I was informed he had signed Papers by the name of Hess— He said he had not, but the mate had— I said I could give him no Passport, without evidence of his being a Citizen of the United States, nor until I should be satisfied that he had not been concerned in such a transaction as that. Lord Viscount Hampden came at One O’Clock, and asked if I could procure him the means of ascertaining whether an Englishman by the name of Hill, was to be found in New-York. He said that nearly six years ago Lady Hampden was walking in Oxford Street, when a woman accosted her apparently in extreme distress; who claimed to have been acquainted with her before; and whom in fact Lady Hampden recollected to have known by the name of Miss Cochrane— This woman now told her that she was married to a Mr Hill, who was at New-York: that she was obliged to go there to join him; and had an infant daughter, that she could not take with her—and she implored Lady Hampden, with so much earnestness to take the child under her protection, that she being very fond of children, and finding her sense of humanity so strongly urged, unwarily promised that she would— She returned home, and for six weeks they heard nothing more of the affair— But then a Carriage drove up from a Public House in the vicinity of his Country House where they then resided, in which was a female infant, with an ample supply of all the clothing necessary for it, and a one hundred pound Bank Note— They had been brought by a woman in another Carriage, a Hackney Coach to the Public House— The Hackney Coachman had been traced; but he had been taken up by this woman in the Street— Had set her down again in the Street upon her return, and knew nothing further of her. About two years afterwards, two Letters were received, with the Dublin Post-mark upon them, dated 20 and 21. December 1811. and signed Philip Ramsay. They enclosed the two halves of another one hundred pound Bank Note, and the first of them a Letter, signed F.
