Hill, without date either of time or place, but purporting to be from the Father of the Child, at New-York— It expressed the highest gratitude to Lady Hampden for her care of the infant— States that the mother had joined her husband, but some months afterwards had been seized with a violent fever, and died— That the father is still prevented by indispensable business from coming to England; but that his friend Ramsay will come and see the Child— The Letters signed Ramsay, made some excuse for being disappointed and prevented from coming. Lord Hampden said they had heard nothing further since that time— The War with America having come on shortly after the receipt of those Letters, they had not been able to have the proper enquiries made at New-York. But the child was now six years old, and at a boarding-school, and he was very desirous of ascertaining whether any such person as this Mr Hill was at New-York— He shewed me the two Letters signed Ramsay, and that signed Hill. They appeared to me to have been all written by the same hand— But the signature F. Hill was in a different, and I remarked to him that I thought it a woman’s hand— He said the hand-writing had appeared suspicious to himself. The Letter signed Hill, being without date of time or place, was also suspicious— He had sometimes thought that some person had wrought upon the kindness of Lady Hampden’s disposition, knowing that they had unfortunately no children of their own; but she had assured him in the strongest manner that she had no knowledge of the persons whatever, except remembering to have been at a dancing school with the woman who had accosted her in Oxford Street, and professed to be the mother of the Child— I told Lord Hampden, that I would make particular enquiries of several respectable Gentlemen, inhabitants of New-York, now here; and also by writing to my friends at New-York itself if he wished; to obtain the desired information— He said perhaps an Advertisement in the New-York Newspapers, might lead to some discovery of the person. I said that I would procure to be inserted in the New-York Prints any thing that he would have drawn up in the form of an Advertisement— He said he would send me one— As he was going away he met my Son John upon the Stairs, and asked me if he was at school— I said not yet— I was looking out for a school— He advised me to send him to Westminster— He always recommended Westminster, and had been there ten years himself. I received a Note from Mr Greuhm the Prussian Chargé d’Affaires on the subject which he had verbally mentioned to me, which I immediately answered. Wrote also to Mr Hughes at Baltimore, and to Meulemeester and Co: at Ghent— Short walk alone before dinner, and a long one after dinner with George in the Park— Letter from Mr Gabriel Penn, recommending a manufacturer of gun powder, to be sent out to America— And two Notes from Mr Ray and Mr Leavenworth, requesting Passports to go to France—which were made out for them.

18. VI: Two morning visitors— The first a Mr Carver, an Englishman, settled and married in the United States— He had a special Passport from Mr Monroe, as Secretary of State, dated in October 1812. and a Letter from Mr Baker who still remained at Washington although the War was declared, to Mr Hamilton, Under Secretary of State, requesting permission that this Mr Carver might be permitted to reside here for the purpose of attending Lectures at a Veterinary school or College— There was a letter from Dr: Rush, stating that this Gentleman was coming out under the patronage and at the expence of several Gentlemen of Philadelphia— Mr Carver stated that when he came out, the War was become so popular in England, that he apprehended, if he delivered Mr Baker’s letter to Mr Hamilton, he should not be permitted to stay— He therefore kept it, and remained here in his character as an English Subject— He has now been here between two and three years— Has attended the Lectures at the Veterinary school, and has a diploma from the College, and an honorary testimony as having himself suggested improvements in the art— But his friends at Philadelphia, have not remitted the funds for his necessary expenditures. He is in considerable arrears at the College— The Russian Ambassador has made him proposals for entering the Emperor’s Service; but he would prefer returning to America, where he is married, and wished me to consult with a Mr Capper, who was prevented by a fit of the gout from calling upon me, whether the benefit of his skill could not be preserved to the United States. I agreed to call upon Mr Capper (whose address he gave me) to-morrow Morning.— The second was a fat, fiery faced Irishman, who said his name was Duncan— That he had been a merchant of Baltimore, and had suffered much by the spoiliations of the British, before the Orders in Council. He expected there would have been an Article in the Treaty of Peace establishing Commissioners to settle such claims, as there had been in Mr Jay’s Treaty—and now he came to ask me whether I thought the English Government, would give indemnity for them— I said that we had used our endeavours to obtain an Article, of that description, in the Treaty of Ghent; but it had been inflexibly refused by the British Government— Then, said he, [“]we have been sacrificed, and I think the Government of the United States ought to pay us”— Address yourself, Sir, said I, to the American Government— I am not the American Government— I only, made the remark, said he— [“]And so, you think our case hopeless?”— “No— I do not say that— Every individual case must rest upon its own merits— I know not what the merits of your case are— You may still apply to the British Government, and if they think you have a just claim for indemnity, I presume they will grant it— As between the Nations, there is no prospect of success in making a claim for you.” He then took leave, apparently dissatisfied.— I received a Letter from Messrs Meulemeester at Ghent, enclosing two others which they had received for me, and a bill of lading for my trunks which they have shipped at Ostend— I had been waiting six weeks for an answer to my letter of 7. June to them, and had written them yesterday a second, enclosing a copy of it, which was ready to be sent by the Post of this day.— The enclosed Letters were one from Messrs: Derby and Prince, dated last December; and the other from Mr E. Newton, an Englishman whom I knew at Boston 1791. and 1792. and with whom I once dined in London in 1795. I have not seen or heard of him since; until now—he writes from Leghorn— The Letter is dated in March last— I called on Messrs: King, Leavenworth, and Ray, and delivered to the two latter of them their Passports. They go for France in the course of the week— I went down to the Consul’s Office, and enquired of Mr Beasley, whether the vessel from Ostend, having my effects on Board, had arrived. From Lloyd’s lists it appeared she had not. I called at the New-York Coffee House and gave Mr Dexter a packet of Letters for my father, and a Letter for Mr Prince at Boston— Mr Dexter said he should go down to Gravesend to-morrow— It was near six, when we came home— Mr Sanders came while we were at dinner, and took our three Sons to go with him to Mr Clarkson’s in the Country— They are to return on Thursday. In the Evening I rode and walked in the Park with Mrs Adams.

19. VI.— Coll: Trumbull called upon me this morning to ask for a Passport for himself and his Lady. He expects to go on Saturday. I went to see Mr Capper, in Ely Place, as I had yesterday promised Mr Carver; and upon conversing with him I found, that he, and Mr Thomas Wilson and some other Gentlemen had made advances to Mr Carver, to the amount of more than two hundred pounds Sterling in the confidence of reimbursement from the Gentlemen of Philadelphia, at whose expence they understood that Mr Carver was pursuing his studies in England.— He shewed me the subscription paper, which was signed by several respectable persons of Philadelphia; but I found on perusing it, that while recommending Mr Carver in strong terms, and saying that after his return he was to exercise his profession, under their patronage, and that of the agricultural Society, it only said that they had subscribed the sums against their respective names amounting in the whole to about 500 dollars, without promising any further contribution— I made this remark, to Mr Capper, and he fully admitted the fact—though he said he had been led by the strong terms in which the paper was drawn up to expect that the subscribers would have contributed further, and in that confidence had made the advances, which he now found inconvenient. He said that Mr Carver had observed the most rigorous economy— He had pursued his studies with the closest assiduity, and was now well qualified as a professor of the veterinary art— There was nothing in his conduct which he could rigorously blame; but he had written to his particular friend one of the subscribers
to the commendatory paper, at Philadelphia, who had answered that Mr Carver had no pretence to claim any additional contribution from those subscribers— I told Mr Capper, that under these Circumstances I could not pay the expences incurred by Mr Carver—and I thought his best expedient would be to accept the proposals of the Russian Ambassador— Mr Capper intimated a doubt whether the Russian Ambassador would make the requisite advances of money—there were considerable arrears of debt at the College, besides the £210 to him and Mr Wilson— He said something of raising a subscription among the American Gentlemen now here— I thought there was little to be expected from that resource— I could at least undertake it— Mr Capper said that Carver had asked him to apply to me, which he had declined— I called at the Spanish Ambassador’s, and returned the visit of Mr Curtoys— Remainder of the day at home, writing—excepting a walk of half an hour after dinner— There were frequent and heavy showers of rain, throughout the day— Received a Letter from Mr Maury at Liverpool, who has received the parcel I sent him last Saturday— Messrs: Clay and Gallatin, were wind-bound on Monday— Received also from the Bavarian Minister a Letter for a man by the name of Mayer, at New-York.

20. V:45. Mr Grubb came this Morning, to enquire if I had any further papers ready for him, and to mention the progress he had made with those which he has with him to copy.— I gave him the last Letters which I have written to the Secretary of State, and requested him to make out a second set of the Papers to be sent with a Duplicate of the Convention to the Secretary of State. I had various applications from Americans, and from foreigners going to America, for Passports— Answered the Note from the Bavarian Minister, and wrote two short Letters— Received Letters from my Son George, and from Mr Sanders at Purfleet, with information that they will stay there at Mr Clarkson’s until Saturday. Letters from Mr Maury at Liverpool, and from Mr George Joy, at the New-England Coffee-house— I called at the Foreign-Office, in Downing Street upon Mr Hamilton, the Under-Secretary of State, to enquire about Mr Maury’s Commission and Exequatur— He promised to have them ready, and to return me the Commission in a few days— I asked him also for an order for the admission of the trunks which I expect from Ostend—of which he took a minute. He said he had thought it best to have Mr Beasley put into the Gazette at once, as Consul-General; after receiving my Note— I told him I presumed it would occasion no inconvenience, as I expected the new appointed Consul, Mr Aspinwall, very shortly— I saw the Sardinian Minister, Count St: Martin d’Aglie in the Anti-chamber. Walked home. Dined at Mr Wellesley-Pole’s, with a small party—his Lady—Lord and Lady Fitzroy Somerset, Mr and Mrs Bagot, Sir Thomasan Officer just returned from America, Messrs: Robinson, Hamilton, Goulburn, and Arbuthnot; with another Gentleman whom I did not know, formed the Company— Lord Fitzroy Somerset was the British Minister at Paris, when I arrived there in February last.— He lost an arm at the late Battle of Waterloo, and appears to be already entirely recovered— I asked Mr Robinson whether any order in Council had issued in consequence of the late Act of Parliament for regulating the Trade with America— He thought not.— I asked him whether he understood the Convention to operate from the time of its signature— He thought, only from the exchange of the Ratifications— I mentioned to him that it was to be in force for four years from the time of the Signature— He thought that was only an expression of limitation.— He said they might act however, upon our act of Congress of 3. March 1815—concerning the discriminating duties— I must attend further to this Subject— I came home about eleven— Mr Murdoch paid us a visit this morning, and gave Mrs Adams a letter from her Sister, Mrs Buchanan.

21. VI: I was quite unwell the whole of this day; which together with the number of visitors who came, made me lose almost the whole day. Mr Grubb came with some of the Papers which I had requested him prepared for this Evening.— Mr Sheafe, Mr Prentice, and another person came for Passports— Mr George Joy, made as usual a long visit, and a Mr Cabbell came to say that he had the Plates and Prints of an excellent Chart of the Coast of Algiers, with the soundings of the Harbour, to dispose of. Mr Carroll and Mr Simson, two Americans, who have been masters of Vessells, sent here as Prisoners of War, totally destitute, and without the means of getting home to the United States— They are among the Prisoners sent from India— I promised to speak for them to Mr Beasley, and referred Mr Carroll to Mr S. Williams, to supply him with a small sum of money upon his bill, which he said he was authorized to draw, on several persons in Boston— And I told him that if Mr Williams should decline doing it for him, to come to me again and I would do it— My wife went out of town, Seven Miles, to look at a house to be let for the Summer—and after dinner we took a walk in Hyde-Park— Lord Bathurst sent me the Gazette Extraordinary with the Dispatch from Lord Castlereagh, and one from the Duke of Otranto to him, announcing that Napoleon Buonanarte, had taken the Resolution of going on board the Bellerophon, Captain Maitland a British ship of the Line, stationed off Rochefort.

22. VI: Mr Beasley called on me this Morning at my request, and I spoke to him concerning the two Americans, sent from India as Prisoners of War, and who applied to me yesterday for assistance.— He told me again that if I listened to all these people, I should never
have any repose, and should be subject to perpetual impositions. I said it was necessary to distinguish between impostors and persons in distress, really entitled to relief— I was convinced that the accounts which these two men gave of themselves were correct. I had referred them to him for such assistance as he could give them according to Law; and had told Carroll that if Mr Williams should decline furnishing him the small sum that he wanted upon his Bill, to come to me and I would— He took their names and promised to see what he could do for them— A black man named Thomas Nelson, a Sailor came in the course of the day, with another tale of distress, and of being turned away from the door of the Consulate— He had been here before; and now came to ask a Passport to go to Liverpool— I gave him a note to Mr: Beasley. Mr Joseph Sansom, a Quaker of Philadelphia, and Mr Delprat came for Passports to go to France— I gave Delprat the first from the Plate— I made up and sent to Mr Beasley a packet for the Secretary of State; to be sent by the Mail-Coach to Mr Maury at Liverpool— Mr Sanders came back with our three boys, very much gratified with their visit to Mr John Clarkson at Purfleet— Mr Sanders dined with us— I walked alone this Evening in Hyde-Park— George was unwell.

23. VII: George was very sick in the Night, and we were up, part of the Night with him. He was better this Morning— Mr Sanders came, and went with the boys to Church— We had a visit from Mr S. Williams who has returned from his excursion to the isle of Wight. I was employed almost all the day in writing to the Secretary of the Treasury— Received Letters from Messrs: Eustis and Everett who have arrived in Holland. They forwarded also to me, a Letter from my Mother, and one from Mr Joseph Hall of Boston. After dinner, Mrs Adams with the boys took a ride— I left them at Hyde Park Corner; and thence walk to Kensington Garden, through it, and returned home, along by the Northern wall of the Park.

24. V: George was again very ill, confined the whole day to his bed. I had the wish and intention to write several letters; but was able to finish only one to Mr Eustis— I gave eight Passports to Americans, five of them Virginians, going to France— The others were of Massachusetts— One a Mr Story, brother to the Judge. A French Lady, Madame de Riviere came also with two Passports, one for her husband; the other for herself and family, to go to America— I endorsed the Passports— Mr George Joy paid me a visit of an hour and a half. Mrs Adams, went to her old friend Dr: Steele, the Apothecary, who attended for many years her father’s family as a Physician— He came and saw George, and prescribed medecines for him— I walked half an hour before dinner, and after dinner took John and Charles with me, and walked to, and through Kensington Garden— Mr: and Mrs Trumbull came to take leave. Mrs Adams being then gone out, the Coll: only came up. He said they expected to leave town to-morrow. Mr Grubb called this morning with some Papers, and I requested him to prepare others as soon as possible, for the purpose of sending duplicates of the Convention by Mr Trumbull.

25. V: I prepared a short Letter to the Secretary of State, and made up the packet to be sent by Mr Trumbull— Wrote also to Mr Shaler; & Commodore Decatur— Called at Mr Trumbull’s lodgings, and saw Mrs Trumbull, to whom I gave the Despatch— I then went to the Counting House of Messrs: Baring; and conversed with Mr Alexander Baring concerning the Instructions from the Secretary of the Treasury, relative to the sale of the Certificates— Mr Baring said there was a balance of about £60,000 due to their house, on the disbursements for prisoners, and that the payment for the Interest upon the Louisiana Loan, would be about £60000 more— The accounts were making out, and he would send them to me open, for my perusal and to be forwarded. He preferred leaving this balance to be provided for by the Secretary of the Treasury, rather than have any of the Certificates sold. He wished for some authority from the American Government, or from the Minister at this Court, for paying the drafts of Mr: Beasley— He said he had no suspicion that Mr Beasley would draw improperly, but they, the Baring’s could assume no responsibility of controul over them— Mr Baring is going to Holland and Switzerland, with the intention of returning by the way of France, in September— I then went to Mr Beasley’s Office, Austin Friars; and gave him the Letters for Mr: Shaler and Commodore Decatur, and for Dr Eustis— Commodore Barney was with him, and told me that he expected to sail next week in the Joseph. Thence I went to Mr S. Williams’s, and requested him to draw upon W. & J. Willink, of Amsterdam, for my funds in their hands. Returned home, and wrote to the Willinks and Van Staphorst’s and also to the Willink’s separately. After dinner, I walked with my Sons John and Charles in and round Hyde Park: after which we rode again round the ring— George was this day much recovered, but not well enough to leave the house— Mrs Adams received this Evening a Letter from Mrs Hewlett, and this day went and paid her a visit.

26. VII: Wrote a short Letter to the Secretary of the Treasury; Mr Grubb called upon me twice— I made up a second packet for the Secretary of State, and sent it just in time for Mr Trumbull, who went down this day to Gravesend— The multitude of visitors and of applications that I have almost every day, renders it impossible to keep my Correspondence regular. I had this day visits from Commodore Barney, who came with a Mr: Barnes for a Passport— Mr Delprat and Buchanan came next—to take leave— Mr Delprat going to-morrow morning for Paris. Mr Buchanan the next day to Holland; to join Dr Eustis and to reside in his family— While they were here, Mr Schley came in, and brought me two Letters with a small packet of French Newspapers from Mr Jackson at Paris, a Sailor boy, a native of Richmond Virginia, starving and having no protection came to implore relief, complaining that he had been turned away from the Consul’s Office— I gave him a note to Mr Beasley. Mr Sanders came, and asked my opinion, and advice, about his project of going to St: Domingo— The primary object is to introduce the systems
of schooling according to the plans of Bell and Lancaster, into that Island— Petion has sent over here to request that some person should be sent out to his part of the Country, for that purpose— Christophe, is represented, as equally earnest for the establishment of schools within his territory— There is a Society here instituted for the purpose of promoting these Schools, and it is that Society which engages Mr Sanders to go— Mr Wilberforce is one of its principal and most active members— Sanders asked me if he did not think he could promote useful relations between St: Domingo and the United States— He intimated that Mr Wilberforce had further projects for which he proposed to raise a Subscription, but I did not understand altogether what they were, nor perceive the propriety of taking any part in them— In the midst of this Conversation Mr Robert Fulk Greville came in— He announced himself as the brother of the Earl of Warwick, and as having married a Sister of Lord Cathcart— He said he was upon the Establishment of the king’s household (he is a groom of the Bed-chamber) and had been many years a member of Parliament, though not one at present— He said he was owner of the whole town of Milford-Haven; that is of the land upon which the town stands, and he appeared labouring with some project by which that place could be used as a Port for the commerce between the United States and this Country— He said and often repeated that he had no settled plan, and that he had no wish to injure the trade of Bristol, Liverpool, or any other place— But he now resided at Great Cumberland Place Number 2. A house which he rented of Lord Ranelagh for a year— If I would call upon him there, at any time when at leisure, he would shew me the Papers, and the proofs of the vast importance as a place of trade, which might be given to Milford-Haven— He hinted that he had now some proposals from the Ministry hereupon the subject, but did not explain to me what they were, not at all distinctly, what was the object of his application to me— I told him that I would call upon him some morning at his house— After dinner, I walked out with the boys, and assisted them in flying their kite in the Park.

27. VII:15. Early this morning I received a Note from Mr Greville, expressing the wish again that I would call upon him at his house, which I answered, promising to wait on him between eleven and one O’Clock to-morrow— Commodore Barney paid me a visit with Mr Richard B. Dorsey, who brought me a Letter of Recommendation from Mr Hellen— Mrs Adams, and the children went to the Fair at Hampstead— Captain Martin Carroll came and told me that Mr Williams had declined supplying him the money that he wanted, to get home— He said he had taken passage on board the Ship Ocean of New-York, and wanted £16. Sterling,—£5 to the Captain to provide Stores, for him, and the rest to pay his debts here— I gave him the £16. and took his bill, upon Alexander Orrok of Boston, payable at sight— There was an invalid Marine, a pensioner, named Renton, who came to me for a Passport, pretending to be a native of Philadelphia, and that his father now lives there— He had been impressed, had then enlisted as a Marine, served seven years on board the magnificent Man of War, was wounded and had a pension of £7–4. which he wanted to sell now for two years purchase, and to work at his trade of a Shoemaker at Philadelphia. He was discharged from the Magnificent in May 1814. and since then had been able to obtain work, only for six weeks, and that was at Leeds in Yorkshire. But as he knew no person at Philadelphia, and could not tell the name even of the Street where he said his father lived (only that it was the Street leading to New-York) and as he spoke with a broad Irish brogue, I dismissed him, with a full conviction that he had never been at Philadelphia— I wrote Letters to Mr Jackson, and to Mr Everett— Sent the first to Mr Delprat who left town this morning.— After dinner I walked with the boys to Kensington Garden and through it— We met the Carriage on the road to Kensington, and the boys rode home— I continued the walk. Mr Steele was here this Morning.

28. VI: Wrote to Mr Harris at St. Petersburg, on the subject of Mr Cutting’s application, for the confirmation of the Emperor of Russia’s grant of the privilege for Steam-boats, and requesting to have our baggage and furniture left at St. Petersburg sent to us— Mr Grubb came, and I gave him my Letter-Book and several papers to be copied— I asked him to look out, and endeavour to find a room or two, which may be kept as an office, while we are in the Country— I have engaged a house, called little Boston House at Ealing, seven miles from London, from the first of August, until the first of January, and we are to go out there next Tuesday, but for the convenience of Americans, who may have occasion to apply for Passports, particularly; or for other business, I think it necessary to have an office in town— Mr Grubb found a place, and informed me of it by a Note— Mr Logan the Schemer of a new Artillery came again with his proposals— I asked him to address them in writing to the American Government, and promised to forward them— A Mr Bradley brought several Virginia land Warrants dated in May 1783. and enquired if they were now of any value— I referred him to enquire of some Citizen of Virginia, or to write to the Country, not knowing myself whether they were not subject to some limitation— A Mr.
Ingersoll, believing himself to be a nephew of Mr Jared Ingersoll of Philadelphia, came to make some enquiries concerning that family— He told me some particulars of his own Story, which was strongly marked with misfortune— I advised him to write to Mr Jared, or Mr Charles Ingersoll, and promised to forward his Letter— At one O’Clock, I went by appointment to Mr Greville’s house Great Cumberland Place, N. 2. and saw him, and the Countess of Mansfield his wife— She is a Sister of Lord Cathcart, and was in Russia with her father when he was Ambassador there— Mr Greville gave me several Charts of Milford-Haven, which he has procured to be made; and shewed me a number of views of the place and of the river below it, taken by himself and under his direction of which he had a Port-folio full. I found his particular object was to obtain from the Lords of the Council an order for making Milford-Haven what they call a bonding Post which by an Act of Parliament they are authorised to do, for the advantage of Commerce— Mr Greville intimated to me, that a recommendation from me, might be of use to obtain the order— I have however not sufficient knowledge of the subject, to justify any such interference on my part— I delivered copies of the 3d: Volume of the Memoirs of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, at Sir Abraham Hume’s for the Geological Society, at Mr Hatchetts for the Royal Institution, at Dr Taylor’s, and to him for the Society of Arts and Manufactures, and at Sir Joseph Banks’s for the Royal Society, and the Society of Antiquaries— I also paid visits to the Ministers of Sicily, Sardinia and Hanover; and to the Chargés d’Affaires of Prussia and Austria— None of them were at home— After dinner I took an hour’s walk, with all the boys. Mr Shaw called upon me yesterday Morning, and told me that Mr Knox, formerly the American Consul at Kingston upon Hull was dead, and Mr Tottie, who had already made an application to be appointed to the office, now renewed with earnestness the request; and was anxious to have a temporary appointment from me— I referred him to Mr Beasley, as now recognized in the character of Consul General; but recommended to him to wait until the arrival of Mr Aspinwall, which is to be expected very shortly.

29. V:45. I went this morning into the cold bath with the three boys, and afterwards walked with them to the Regent’s Park and round it before breakfast. After breakfast I walked out again to a look at some Carriages for sale, but found none to suit me. Mr Grubb came and brought back the papers I had last given him to be copied— I gave Passports to Messrs: S. Bullard, J. F. Dana, C. Thorndike and J. E. Burrell, Americans; A Coll. Richardson, called upon me again with a Mr Hughes, who is going out to America as Mr Bagot’s private Secretary. Mrs Adams went out again to see the house that we have taken at Ealing, and we made some preparations for our departure— I received a Letter from Mr Robert Montgomery of Alicant, with the information that on the fourth of this Month, Commodore Decatur, had concluded a Peace with the Dey and Regency of Algiers— The Ships and Prisoners taken to be restored on both sides, and no future tribute or presents to be paid— The Restoration of the Algerine ships, is a very bad stipulation, and is equivalent to a heavy present tribute. There seems also to me, to be no guarantee for the permanency of a Peace, during which nothing is to be paid as inducement for the Algerines to observe it. I therefore regret very much that this peace has been made, and found the effect upon the Americans to whom I mentioned it was the same— Mr Baring sent me the Statement of his accounts with the Treasury, and his letter accompanying them to the Secretary of the Treasury.— I read them over, and also several more of the papers transmitted by Mr Sumter— Mr Sanders called here after dinner— I took an Evening walk with Mrs Adams, who purchased some further Articles for our Country Residence.

30. VI. Mr Sanders came this morning, and went with the boys to Church at the Chapel in Vere Street. He dined with us, and they all went in the Evening to the Foundling Hospital— I engaged Peter Pio, in my service as Butler, from the first of the ensuing Month— Some further arrangements were made for our removal to Ealing; but I was occupied the greatest part of the day, in making out my quarterly account, and in writing to the Secretary of State— I walked in the Evening in Hyde Park.

31. VI:45. Dr. B. S. Barton of Philadelphia, called upon me, with his Son— He brought me a Letter of Recommendation from Mr Dallas the Secretary of the Treasury. He is last from France, and likewise brought me a Letter from Mr Jackson at Paris; and one from Mr Boyd to Mrs. Adams— We had also a morning visit from Mr and Mrs Hewlett. I took to Commodore Barney’s lodgings two Packets of despatches for the Secretary of State— He was not at home and his Servant knew not when he would leave town, but believed some day this week— Mr Grubb had called this morning, with the papers which I gave him on Saturday— I went to No: 25. Charles Street Westminster, and engaged the two Chambers which Mr Grubb had recommended to me; for an house to alight at when I have occasion to come to town— Mr Grubb will attend at them from ten O’Clock till four every day. I called at the Engraver Silvester’s at N. 27 in the Strand to enquire for the Legation Seal that I had ordered. It was not ready— I called at Richard’s Coffee-House Fleet-Street, to see Mr Thorndike and Mr Randolph who had paid me visits last week— Mr Thorndike is gone to France, and Mr Randolph was out. Thence I went to Mr Williams’s Finsbury Square— He was not at home, but I gave his brother Mr Charles Williams, a Letter to Messrs: Willink and Van Staphorst of Amsterdam authorizing Mr Williams to draw upon them for my account— I stopped at the General
Post-Office, to give notice of my removal, and to enquire if Letters could be delivered to me by their Carriers at Ealing. I found they could not, and one of the Clerks to whom I spoke advised me to write to Mr Freeling the Secretary and mention to him the place, where I wished to have my Letters delivered. I walked home, and at eleven in the Evening went to a party at Mrs Wellesley-Pole’s— There were about seventy persons in the Company—two thirds of them at least, Ladies. Excepting the family, I found very few of my acquaintance—Lord Graves—Count St. Martin d’Aglie the Sardinian Minister, Mr Neumann the Austrian Charge d’Affaires, Mr: and Madame Rayneval, and Sir Gore Ouseley to whom I was introduced. He arrived, only two days since from St: Petersburg. I had some Conversation with him on the subject of Persia, whence he comes, and much with Mr Bagot on the topics upon which his Mission to America will be occupied. It was between one and 2 in the Morning when I came home.

Day. The employment and distribution of my time this Month, has been much like the last, excepting that I have been released from the engagements proceeding from the Negotiation of the Convention— The Arrears of my Diary have been retrieved, and the last fortnight, I have generally kept along with the current. I have also had more leisure for my Correspondence, and of course have attended more to it— Still a great portion of my time is consumed by visits, and by Applications for Passports, American Sailors, and English Projectors.— From this time however, a great and immediate change in my course of life will take place. We are to remove to-morrow into the Country.
